verses.kjv: As snow in summer, and as rain in harvest, so honour is not seemly for a fool.
verses.ct: Snow doesn't belong in summer, and rain doesn't belong at harvest time — in the same way, honor doesn't belong to a fool.

verses.kjv: As the bird by wandering, as the swallow by flying, so the curse causeless shall not come.
verses.ct: Like a sparrow darting around or a swallow swooping through the air, an undeserved curse will never land on its target.

verses.kjv: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the ass, and a rod for the fool’s back.
verses.ct: A whip is for the horse, a bridle is for the donkey, and a rod is for the back of a fool.

verses.kjv: Answer not a fool according to his folly, lest thou also be like unto him.
verses.ct: Don't respond to a fool on his own terms, or you'll end up just like him.

verses.kjv: Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he be wise in his own conceit.
verses.ct: Respond to a fool on his own terms, or he'll think he's actually wise.

verses.kjv: He that sendeth a message by the hand of a fool cutteth off the feet, and drinketh damage.
verses.ct: Sending a message through a fool is like cutting off your own feet and drinking poison.

verses.kjv: The legs of the lame are not equal: so is a parable in the mouth of fools.
verses.ct: A wise saying coming from a fool is as useless as the dangling legs of a paralyzed person.

verses.kjv: As he that bindeth a stone in a sling, so is he that giveth honour to a fool.
verses.ct: Giving honor to a fool is like tying a stone into a sling so it can't be thrown.

verses.kjv: As a thorn goeth up into the hand of a drunkard, so is a parable in the mouth of fools.
verses.ct: A wise saying in the mouth of a fool is like a thorn bush grabbed by a drunk — it only causes harm.

verses.kjv: The great God that formed all things both rewardeth the fool, and rewardeth transgressors.
verses.ct: An archer who shoots at everyone who passes by — that's what someone is like who hires a fool or hires random strangers.

verses.kjv: As a dog returneth to his vomit, so a fool returneth to his folly.
verses.ct: Just as a dog goes back to eat its own vomit, a fool keeps repeating his stupidity.

verses.kjv: Seest thou a man wise in his own conceit? there is more hope of a fool than of him.
verses.ct: Do you see someone who thinks he's wise? There's actually more hope for a fool than for him.

verses.kjv: The slothful man saith, There is a lion in the way; a lion is in the streets.
verses.ct: The lazy person says, 'There's a lion out on the road! A lion is roaming the streets!'

verses.kjv: As the door turneth upon his hinges, so doth the slothful upon his bed.
verses.ct: A door swings back and forth on its hinges, and a lazy person rolls back and forth in bed.

verses.kjv: The slothful hideth his hand in his bosom; it grieveth him to bring it again to his mouth.
verses.ct: A lazy person reaches into the dish but can't even be bothered to lift the food back to his mouth.

verses.kjv: The sluggard is wiser in his own conceit than seven men that can render a reason.
verses.ct: A lazy person considers himself smarter than 7 people who can give well-reasoned answers.

verses.kjv: He that passeth by, and meddleth with strife belonging not to him, is like one that taketh a dog by the ears.
verses.ct: Getting involved in someone else's argument when it's none of your business is like grabbing a stray dog by the ears.

verses.kjv: As a mad man who casteth firebrands, arrows, and death,
verses.ct: Like a crazed person shooting flaming arrows and spreading death,

verses.kjv: So is the man that deceiveth his neighbour, and saith, Am not I in sport?
verses.ct: that's what someone is like who tricks his neighbor and then says, 'Relax, I was only joking!'

verses.kjv: Where no wood is, there the fire goeth out: so where there is no talebearer, the strife ceaseth.
verses.ct: Without fuel, a fire dies out; without a gossip, conflict comes to an end.

verses.kjv: As coals are to burning coals, and wood to fire; so is a contentious man to kindle strife.
verses.ct: Charcoal keeps embers burning and wood keeps flames alive — in the same way, a quarrelsome person keeps conflict going.

verses.kjv: The words of a talebearer are as wounds, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.
verses.ct: The words of a gossip are like tasty snacks — they slide right down into a person's core.

verses.kjv: Burning lips and a wicked heart are like a potsherd covered with silver dross.
verses.ct: Smooth talk paired with an evil heart is like a cheap clay pot coated with a thin layer of silver glaze.

verses.kjv: He that hateth dissembleth with his lips, and layeth up deceit within him;
verses.ct: A person who hates you will disguise it with his words, while inside he's storing up deception.

verses.kjv: When he speaketh fair, believe him not: for there are seven abominations in his heart.
verses.ct: When he speaks kindly, don't trust him, because his heart is full of disgusting intentions.

verses.kjv: Whose hatred is covered by deceit, his wickedness shall be shewed before the whole congregation.
verses.ct: He may hide his hatred behind deception, but his wickedness will eventually be exposed in front of everyone.

verses.kjv: Whoso diggeth a pit shall fall therein: and he that rolleth a stone, it will return upon him.
verses.ct: Whoever digs a pit will fall into it themselves, and whoever rolls a boulder will have it come rolling back on them.

verses.kjv: A lying tongue hateth those that are afflicted by it; and a flattering mouth worketh ruin.
verses.ct: A lying tongue hates the people it hurts, and a flattering mouth leads to destruction.
